headline.main: MARIJUANA AND PRO BASKETBALL -- A special report.; N.B.A.'s Uncontrolled Substance.

docs.abstract: National Basketball Association players, former players, agents and executives say that contrary to wholesome image marketed by league, 60 to 70 percent of its 350-plus players smoke marijuana and drink excessively; two decades ago, league nearly collapsed under perception that its athletes were high on cocaine; many people say NBA's 14-year-old drug policy is so antiquated and ineffective that it protects players despite behavior that is illegal and commonplace; under collective bargaining agreement, league allows mandatory drug testing of rookies only, does not list marijuana as prohibited substance, and prevents teams from testing veterans for cocaine and heroin except under rare circumstances; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Contrary to the wholesome image marketed by the National Basketball Association, 60 to 70 percent of its 350-plus players smoke marijuana and drink excessively, according to conversations with more than two dozen players, former players, agents and basketball executives. ''If they tested for pot, there would be no league,'' said Richard Dumas, the former Phoenix Suns guard who was banned from the league for drug and alcohol use and is now playing in Europe. ''Weed is something guys grow up doing, and there's no reason for them to stop. Because almost everyone does it, no one wants to test for it. They're afraid to.''

headline.main: PUZZLE IN A BOTTLE -- A special report.; In Vitamin Mania, Millions Take a Gamble on Health

docs.abstract: Special report, Puzzle in a Bottle, on mania for vitamin and mineral supplements among health-conscious consumers; American consumers are spending $6.5 billion on year on supplements in vast, largely unregulated experiment with substances that may be helpful, harmful or ineffective; there is little, if any, evidence that supplements can compensate for careless eating habits and some known dangers of vitamin use; table; photo (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: Whatever health-conscious consumers might be looking for, there is a vitamin or mineral pill that promises it. Products for sale purport to offer cancer protection, a hardier heart, extra energy, enhanced immunity, less stress, a longer life, an antidote to pollution, stronger bones, less body fat, relief from premenstrual syndrome, athletic prowess and heightened sexual powers. ''Vitamania,'' as some critics call it, is sweeping the country, with sales of vitamins and minerals soaring to records.
